content: You may not be as financially secure as you’d like to be, but you’re not in the same position you were before: you have no student loans, no car loans and a good credit score.* Banks are fickle, and employees can be incompetent. It could be worth trying again. (Maybe ask for a minimal amount with the intent of raising it later? I don’t know how LoCs work, to be honest.) I know how it feels when you are unpleasantly surprised at something you thought went well. Once I was encouraged to apply for a position by the hiring manager who told me she was looking for ‘someone like me’. I didn’t get the job - she told me that my application was really really bad! (Apparently, government wants pages and pages rather than something concise — it’s quantity they want. Don’t list one example, list them ALL.) The rejection stung despite not even being super-invested in the outcome. *may not be entirely accurate but there’s been improvement, is what I’m saying.
